title: Queenstown Airport's record profit
text:
Last updated 12:31, August 21 2015 supplied 
Aerial shot of Queenstown Airport. 
Queenstown Airport Corporation says a strong period of outstanding growth is behind record profit in the last financial year. 
The Corporation has just released it's annual report recording Net Profit after Tax of $8.3 million - up 25 per cent from the previous year's profit of $6.6 million. 
Total revenue increased 13 per cent to $24.8 million. 
Board Chairman John Gilks said the company was paying it's largest ever dividend of $5.2 million to its two shareholders, up 19 per cent from $4.3 million last year. 
Majority shareholder, the Queenstown Lakes District Council, would receive 75.1 per cent ($3.9 million) payable to majority shareholder Queenstown Lakes District Council - about $168 per rateable property in the district. The remaining 24.9 per cent would be paid to minority shareholder Auckland International Airport Limited. 
Gilks said the growth in revenue was driven by strong passenger volumes, greater retail spend per passenger, more car parking and improved commercial leasing revenues. 
Total passenger movements through the airport increased 12 per cent, setting a new record of 1.4 million passengers in the 12 months to June 2015. 
The main contributors to the increase in passengers were strong trans-Tasman passenger growth, buoyed by the recommencement of Jetstar's Gold Coast service, and domestic passenger numbers hitting the one million mark for the first time. 
International passenger numbers were up 29 per cent to 398,000 while domestic passengers rebounded, up 6 per cent to 1,001,000. 
To manage the demands of growth and improve passenger flow, the corporation complete key infrastructure projects during the year including a public carpark expansion, a temporary 'pop-up' structure to expand the international arrivals area for winter 2014 and a new international terminal for winter 2015 which has doubled the size of the airport's international operations. 
A commercial and retail improvement programme started two years ago had also pushed up the rate of revenue growth from those activities exceeding that of aeronautical. 
New offerings in the past year included Airspresso Caf√© and Bar, the Manaia Passenger Lounge and TravelPharm. 
Gilks said the appeal of Queenstown and the surrounding region as a domestic and international travel destination remained strong. 
The forward schedules of Air New Zealand, Jetstar, Qantas, and Virgin Australia remained strong. 
"In particular, Air New Zealand's commitment to adding more than 110,000 additional seats between Queenstown and Auckland in FY2016 is extremely positive," he said. 
Key growth opportunities included: 
- Planning to introduce evening flights 
- Creating a new aviation precinct with the proposed acquisition of approximately 16ha of land (Lot 6) from developer Remarkables Park Limited 
- Working closely with local government and businesses in Queenstown to encourage investment in visitor infrastructure 
- Continuing the rollout of QAC's 20-year noise mitigation works plan for acoustic treatment packages in the homes identified as most affected by aircraft noise. - Stuff
